ABOUT ME

ABOUT

Hey there! I am Rather Hamid, a graduate student, aerospace engineer, and researcher from Germany.

MS Student @ Universität Bremen

I am pursuing a Master of Science (MS) with a concentration in the design, integration, and analysis of aerospace systems at Universität Bremen and hold a Bachelor of Science in Aerospace Engineering. I am currently a Student Researcher in the Fiber, composites & cryogenics lab. In this role, I design and integrate test equipment for cryogenic materials, and crucially, I also develop and automate the data analysis pipelines for these experiments. I use Python, Pandas, Plotly, other libraries and PowerBI to process, analyze, and visualize the test results, turning raw sensor data into actionable insights for material selection.

Sports: Camping, Volleyball, and Fitness

Hobbies: Reading technical papers and exploring new technologies

My current work as a Student Researcher at Faserinstitut Bremen is focused on materials for next-generation propulsion. I am designing and building test stands to analyze how composite materials and adhesives behave in cryogenic environments, specifically for hydrogen fuel tanks. This role combines hands-on design and simulations with hardware integration. A key part of this role is developing the Python-based data workflows to process and analyze the permeation test results, turning raw sensor data into meaningful insights.

CAREER

Werkstudent @ Faserinstitut Bremen

Developing and automating data analysis pipelines in Python (Pandas, Matplotlib) to process and visualize experimental data from materials science research.

My work supports high-profile projects like HyTank (an Airbus project) and WaGuPa, focusing on materials for cryogenic liquid hydrogen (LH2) storage.

Designed, built, and commissioned a high-pressure helium permeation test stand, integrating all hardware, sensors, and DAQ systems from the ground up.

Conducting cryogenic material characterization for the HyTank project, including tensile tests on composites submerged in liquid nitrogen (−196°C).

Performing coupled Ansys (CFD) simulations for material analysis in composite tank structures.

Werkstudent

Focused on the modeling and simulation of electrochemical systems, such as hydrogen electrolyzers and fuel cells, to understand their behavior within a larger grid.

Conducted energy system analysis by testing the models against four different power input data sets representing various renewable electricity supply scenarios.

My work directly supported the techno-economic assessment of these hydrogen systems.

Utilized libraries like Pyomo, SciPy, Pandas, etc to build and run the simulations.

Hamid Rather

Aerospace Engineering master's student and data analyst with 4+ years of experience at the intersection of hardware and software. I design, build, and test complex systems, from rocket engine test stands to cryogenic permeation rigs. I write Python code to model and analyze cutting-edge hardware, from staged-combustion rocket engines to cryogenic material test stands.


Bremen, Germany
abrather@uni-bremen.de

Universität Bremen, Bremen, Germany

My master's focus at Universität Bremen is a blend of Aerospace Engineering, and Computer Science, specializing in the intersection of hardware and software. My concentration integrates dynamic systems (rocket propulsion ), optimization (Python-based data analysis ), and cyber-physical systems (hands-on test stand design and integration )

Expected August 2026
Master of Science, Aerospace Engineering, MS.

SRM University, Chennai, India

The Aerospace Engineering curriculum at SRM Institute of Science and Technology provided me with the education and training necessary to design, analyze, and visualize complex aerospace systems. My program's focus on Design and Space Propulsion and Fluid Flow Visualization & Analysis gave me a strong foundation in both computational simulation and hands-on experimental work.

Graduated June 2020
Aerospace Engineering, B.Tech.

HyTank - Cryogenic Hydrogen Storage

Overview

Development of composite tanks for cryogenic liquid hydrogen (LH2) storage for aerospace applications, including materials characterization and permeation testing

Details

HyTank is an Airbus-led project focused on developing advanced composite materials and tank designs for storing cryogenic liquid hydrogen at −196°C. The project involves cryogenic material characterization, high-pressure helium permeation testing, and coupled Ansys CFD simulations for material analysis in composite tank structures.

Technologies

  • Composite Materials
  • Cryogenic Testing
  • Ansys CFD
  • Python Data Analysis

Key Features

  • Cryogenic material characterization at −196°C
  • High-pressure helium permeation test stand
  • Coupled CFD simulations for tank structures
  • Experimental data analysis pipelines
View Project

Overview

Research project focused on advanced composite materials and manufacturing processes at Faserinstitut Bremen

Details

WaGuPa is a materials science research initiative investigating innovative composite manufacturing techniques and material properties. The project involves experimental testing, data analysis, and development of new approaches to composite material fabrication and characterization.

Technologies

  • Data Analysis

Key Features

Overview

Details

BENENE is a research project exploring novel fiber composite materials and their applications. The work includes simulation, testing, digitization, and documentation of fiber composite systems with applications in various industrial sectors.

HyBit - Resilient Energy Systems

Overview

Mathematical modeling and simulation of resilient energy systems with focus on hydrogen electrolyzers and fuel cells for renewable energy integration

Details

HyBit project focuses on developing mathematical models in Python to simulate and analyze complex, resilient energy systems. The work involves modeling electrochemical systems such as hydrogen electrolyzers and fuel cells to understand their behavior within larger renewable electricity grids and support techno-economic assessments.

Technologies

  • Python
  • Pyomo
  • SciPy
  • Energy System Modeling

Key Features

  • Mathematical modeling of electrochemical systems
  • Energy system optimization and simulation
  • Testing against multiple renewable scenarios
  • Techno-economic assessment support

View Project GitHub

Master Project - Cryogenic Microcracks in CFRP

Overview

Development and validation of a model for the simulation of cryogenically thermally induced microcracks in CFRP

Details

This research project aims to provide a reliable way to improve the quality and durability of CFRP components for use in challenging cryogenic environments. The combination of experimental testing and simulation enables a well-founded analysis of how manufacturing processes interact with the structural performance of CFRP under cryogenic conditions. By comparing the simulation and test results, this project work provided a deep understanding of how material design and structural configuration can be made better to minimize microcrack formation. The findings served as a crucial guide for the future design and engineering of cryo-safe CFRP structures, ensuring their durability and reliability for the next generation of hydrogen technology applications.
This research investigates the micromechanical behavior and damage evolution of a high-performance Carbon Fiber Reinforced Polymer (CFRP) composite subjected to extreme cryogenic thermal cycling. Using Abaqus/Standard and Python scripting, a 3D Representative Volume Element (RVE) with a variable fiber volume fraction was generated to simulate a cryogenic thermal cycle. The simulation explicitly models the fiber-matrix interface using cohesive elements to capture debonding and micro-cracking phenomena driven by the significant mismatch in the Coefficient of Thermal Expansion (CTE) between the fiber and the matrix. The model incorporates Periodic Boundary Conditions (PBCs) to ensure the RVE accurately represents the bulk material behavior.

Technologies

  • CAD (CATIA)
  • Autoclave manufacturing
  • Microcracks
  • Cryogenic testing
  • Composite laminates
  • Thermal analysis
  • Finite Element Analysis
  • Material characterization

Key Features

  • Manufacturing of CFRP plates using autoclave process
  • Cryogenic thermal cycling
  • Python scripting for RVE generation
  • Finite Element Analysis with Abaqus/Standard
  • Modeling of fiber-matrix interface with cohesive elements
  • Microcrack analysis and validation against experimental data
View Project GitHub

Real-Time Credit Card Financial Dashboard

Overview

Development of a comprehensive Power BI dashboard using SQL and DAX to monitor financial key figures and customer behavior

Details

This project aimed to bridge the gap between raw transaction data and actionable business insights by developing a real-time monitoring system for credit card operations. The solution enables stakeholders to control project key figures and visualize complex financial data, facilitating faster and more accurate internal management reporting. By synthesizing data from over 46 million transactions, the dashboard provides immediate visibility into $57 million in revenue and $8 million in interest earned. The analysis revealed critical risk segments, including a 6.06% delinquency rate, allowing for the implementation of data-driven risk mitigation strategies.
From a technical perspective, the project involved orchestrating a complete ETL pipeline. Raw data was imported, cleaned, and structured within a PostgreSQL database using SQL. Advanced DAX functions were defined to calculate dynamic measures for weekly trends and customer segmentation. The final Power BI visualization automates the reporting process, ensuring data consistency and plausibility while offering interactive filtering by geography, card category, and customer demographics.

Technologies

  • Power BI
  • SQL (PostgreSQL)
  • DAX
  • ETL Pipelines
  • Data Modeling
  • Data Quality Management
  • Financial Analysis
  • Data Visualization

Key Features

  • Automated data extraction and transformation using SQL
  • Real-time monitoring of $57M revenue and transaction trends
  • Dynamic KPI calculation using advanced DAX measures
  • Interactive customer segmentation (Age, Job, Income)
  • Risk analysis and delinquency rate tracking
  • Weekly trend reporting for internal management
View Project

Experimental Heat Transfer & Thermal Management Analysis

Overview

A comprehensive experimental study on passive heat transfer enhancement techniques, focusing on phase change, geometric optimization, and surface modulation.

Details

Efficient thermal management is critical for the reliability of modern high-power electronic systems. This project series investigated three distinct passive cooling strategies to quantify their impact on heat dissipation rates. The first phase focused on Phase Change Thermal Management, analyzing the performance of Heat Pipes. By characterizing the two-phase flow mechanism (evaporation and condensation), the study demonstrated how utilizing the latent heat of vaporization allows for an effective thermal conductivity that significantly outperforms solid copper conductors.
The second phase explored Geometric Optimization through a parametric study of extended surfaces (fins). The experiment isolated the effects of orientation (vertical vs. horizontal) on natural convection, quantifying the variation in the convective heat transfer coefficient (h) to determine optimal heat sink configurations driven by buoyancy effects.
The final phase investigated Passive Turbulence Induction. By introducing controlled surface roughness using wire mesh overlays, the study analyzed the disruption of the thermal boundary layer. The results showed a direct correlation between surface irregularity and an increased Nusselt number, proving that tripping the boundary layer from laminar to turbulent effectively enhances the overall heat transfer rate without active energy input.

Technologies

  • Thermocouple Data Acquisition
  • Two-Phase Flow
  • Fluid Dynamics
  • Experimental Design
  • Thermal Resistance Networks
  • Error Analysis
  • Dimensionless Numbers (Nu, Ra, Pr)

Key Features

  • Performance characterization of Heat Pipes vs. Solid Conductors
  • Calculation of effective thermal conductivity enhancements
  • Parametric analysis of Fin Orientation on natural convection
  • Quantification of convective heat transfer coefficients (h)
  • Boundary layer manipulation using surface roughness (wire mesh)
  • Correlation of Nusselt number increases with turbulence induction
View Project GitHub

Experimental Fluid Dynamics & Flow Visualization Platform

Overview

End-to-end development of a custom wind tunnel facility, high-speed optical analysis of jet flows, and computational data processing.

Details

This extensive portfolio of projects centers on the complete lifecycle of experimental fluid mechanics, moving from hardware fabrication to data-driven discovery. The initiative was divided into three critical phases to investigate the complex physics of jet impingement and vortex shedding.
Phase I: Facility Design & Fabrication The foundation of this research was the ground-up development of a custom Mini Jet Impingement Wind Tunnel. Over a rigorous 7-month period, the facility was designed, prototyped, and assembled. This required a focus on system integration and "frugal engineering," utilizing cost-effective commercial components to construct a precision testing rig capable of delivering stable, controllable airflow for experimental validation.
Phase II: Optical Diagnostics (Flow Visualization) With the facility operational, the focus shifted to advanced visualization techniques. Utilizing a departmental High-Speed Camera, experimental campaigns were conducted to capture the transient nature of fluid motion. The research meticulously analyzed the evolution of flow structures issuing from various nozzle geometries and the stagnation dynamics of jet impingement on flat plates, revealing complex vortex interactions invisible to standard observation.
Phase III: Computational Analysis (MATLAB) The final phase bridged the gap between qualitative footage and quantitative engineering data. Custom MATLAB algorithms were developed to process the high-speed imagery. This post-processing pipeline allowed for the extraction of key flow features, the generation of precise velocity profiles, and the mathematical characterization of turbulence intensity, converting raw experimental data into actionable insights.

Technologies

  • Wind Tunnel Design
  • High-Speed Imaging
  • MATLAB & Image Processing
  • Rapid Prototyping
  • System Integration
  • Fluid Mechanics
  • Optical Diagnostics
  • Experimental Data Analysis

Key Features

  • Design and construction of a custom Mini Jet Impingement Wind Tunnel (7-month timeline)
  • Integration of commercial components for cost-effective system design
  • High-speed visualization of jet flow structures and vortex dynamics
  • Analysis of jet impingement on flat plate surfaces
  • Development of MATLAB scripts for automated image post-processing
  • Quantitative extraction of velocity profiles and flow characteristics
View Project GitHub
